docs.lead_paragraph: CHRISTY WAGNER was a student at Huntington High School when, in 1997, she participated in a mock trial that scrambled her career plans. ''I was interested in science and I expected to become a doctor or a scientist at that point, but then I joined the mock trial team for a sexual abuse case,'' Ms. Wagner said last week. Intrigued by her exposure to the legal system, Ms. Wagner went on to attend Hofstra Law School in Hempstead.

headline.main: First, Let's Hire All the Lawyers (and Teachers)

docs.abstract: Article on rise in number of jobs in major professional groups on Long Island since beginning of decade, particularly lawyers and teachers; New York State Labor Department estimates that 1,740 new jobs for lawyers will be created by 2010, nearly 21 percent jump during decade; fastest-growing sector overall is health care, with occupations involving diagnostics and treatment growing more than 23 percent; overall job growth is expected to exceed 11 percent; jobs for primary, secondary and special education teachers are expected to increase by 5,060, or nearly 11 percent, this decade; photo (M)
docs.snippet: CHRISTY WAGNER was a student at Huntington High School when, in 1997, she participated in a mock trial that scrambled her career plans.    ''I was interested in science and I expected to become a doctor or a scientist at that point, but then I joined...
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Frustration with the Bush administration's shortsighted restrictions on embryonic stem cell research has found its most extreme expression in an ambitious ballot measure that will be presented to California voters in the November elections. The measure calls for the state to borrow some $3 billion in the next decade or so to finance stem cell research in the state's medical schools and other nonprofit research institutions, with priority given to the kind of research that is now barred from receiving federal support under President Bush's policy. The amount of money is staggering, an order of magnitude as great as what is now spent by the federal government on the limited embryonic stem cell research the president is willing to support. In effect, the proposal would have California pick up the leadership role that President Bush has abdicated. Californians will decide if this is the way they wish to spend their public money. But there is little doubt that the rest of us stand to benefit greatly if this promising field of research gets a huge boost.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds that frustration with Bush administration's shortsighted restrictions on embryonic stem cell research is evident in California initiative that would have state borrow $3 billion over next decade to finance such research; says question is whether Californians want to pay for medical advances that will benefit not just themselves but everyone else
docs.snippet: If California decides to pick up the leadership role on stem cell research there is little doubt that the rest of us stand to benefit greatly.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki has signed into law a requirement for hospitals to show mothers of newborn babies a video about shaken baby syndrome before they leave the hospital. The law, signed at White Plains Hospital Center yesterday, will take effect at the end of November and require all birthing centers and hospitals to show a state-approved education video, although mothers can decline to watch it. In 2002, the state Health Department reported that six children died because of shaken baby syndrome and another 31 children were hospitalized with related injuries. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Bill On Shaken Baby Syndrome Signed

docs.abstract: New York Gov George Pataki signs law requiring hospitals to show video about shaken baby syndrome to mothers of newborns before they leave hospital (S)

byline.original: By Jennifer Medina (NYT); Compiled by George James

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S a rite of passage for many expectant parents: baby's first ultrasound. The fuzzy images of the fetus, produced during an examination in an obstetrician's office, are prized by couples, passed around proudly among friends and relatives. Now, trying to capitalize on this phenomenon, a number of companies are selling elective ultrasounds that have little to do with neonatal health. The services, often in small offices or shopping malls, amount to fetal photo studios and use newer 3-D ultrasound technology to produce more realistic images than conventional machines.
docs.abstract: Some companies are selling elective ultrasound images and video of unborn babies; some doctors and federal regulators feel practice may pose health risks; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Ultrasound images from the womb are increasingly being made not for medical purposes but by companies offering expectant parents a sort of prebirth viewing.
